reviewText:
I've always been wary of games that try to tackle historical events, because they rarely seem to get their subject matter right. There's something disrespectful about historical games like the early Call of Duty titles, which placed players into real wars that real people fought and died in, exploiting those experiences by transforming them into mindless entertainment for the masses. Tackling this kind of heavy subject matter requires a degree of nuance that bleak loadscreen quotations or pressing F to pay respects don't even begin to provide.

1979 Revolution: Black Friday doesn't share those problems. Created by Rockstar Games veteran and Iranian national Navid Khonsari, whose family escaped the turmoil the title aims to portray, the game tells the story of the Iranian Revolution of 1979, which lead to the deposition of the Shah of Iran and the end of the Pahlavi dynasty. The influence of this period in Iranian history cannot be understated, yet knowledge of this point in history remains woefully elusive to the American public consciousness.

It's fitting, then, that the game starts out with so much exposition. This isn't a Call of Duty title looking to capitalize on history as a mere backdrop to action-heavy gameplay. The Telltale-esque title places players into a series of unfolding events as an Iranian photojournalist recently returned home from Germany. Early in the story, players will take a walk through a protest-crowded street, snapping pictures and listening to their companion expound on the issues facing Iran leading up to the 1979 revolution. Westernization, income inequality, government censorship - the developers are clearly aware of their audience's unfamiliarity with the setting and do a fantastic job of the setting the stage for the players.

It all comes naturally; your character, after all, has been out of the country for awhile, so it stands to reason that he might need to be caught up on current events. After snapping a photo, players are presented with a quick blurb of information and given the option to learn more, leading them to small snippets of Iran's history in the game's journal.

Fortunately, unlike many titles tackling heavy subject matter, 1979 Revolution is at least somewhat able to stand on its own as an entertaining game. It's informative without being preachy, and engages players with choice and consequence and quick-time event systems Telltale Games or Life is Strange veterans will find immediately familiar.

1979 Revolution is best described as a political thriller, and it isn't long until your jaunt down exposition lane is interrupted by the proverbial ♥♥♥♥ hitting the fan. It's a character driven story, showing Iranian nationals with a variety of different political and religious views reacting as their country is turned upside down. The voice acting is crucially well executed, thanks to a cadre of veteran film actors. Almost everyone involved with the project has a prior work that I've seen or am at least familiar with; I recognized the voice of Mozhan Marnò from The Blacklist, House of Cards, and A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night immediately.

The game is an indie title though, and you can tell that the funds for its actors may have been diverted from other areas of its limited budget. The art assets in particular leave a bit to be desired; it will quickly become apparent that character models and animations are being reused for the game's extras. In a game like this though, pursuing flawless writing and voice acting for its characters ultimately should trump almost everything else.

1979 Revolution does end a bit abruptly. It's not as bad as say, The Banner Saga, but I was expecting the narrative to go on for an additional chapter, or maybe for it to show a bit more of the revolution's aftermath. It's not a bad ending per se, but it does sort of build and build and then just end in the middle of its own climax.

Overall, the game succeeds in bringing a historically accurate, better understanding of the titular revolution to those who play it. It's not a deep look and it doesn't get too bogged down in historical details, instead focusing broadly on the people of Iran as they lived through this formative moment in their nation's history. 1979 Revolution is worth checking out on that basis alone if you're interested in experiencing a sample of pre-revolution Iran and how it evolved to become the nation we have today.

If you're not interested in that, I'd find the the title harder to recommend. This is a game of ideas, and it follows that the title is inextricably linked to the message it wants its players to receive. Standing on its own, its narrative isn't as satisfying as a Telltale Game and its gameplay doesn't touch Life is Strange, but if you're generally interested in experiencing a bit of history, that can make the title shine.

1979 Revolution: Black Friday is a short game at just over two hours of total playtime, and is available on Steam for a full price of $12. I'll leave the value judgment up to you.

1979 Revolution: Black Friday is, so far, possibly the most significant game I’ve ever encountered. True, I’ve played games like Beeswing, that were profound on a personal level, but this game is profound on global, historical and personal levels. For this reason, and others, it has already drawn hostility purely for political and social reasons, so I feel justified in attempting to redirect attention toward back toward this important and interesting game while attempting to maintain context. (This is a very early review on a game that is impressive from the very start, and that I expect to elaborate on soon.)

1979 Revolution: Black Friday is a game about the overthrow of the Shah of Iran in 1979, to be replaced by religious fundamentalists. That event is very important to those of us that are Americans (regrettably, the only context I have) because this nation was fully responsible for placing the Shah’s oppressive regime in place, with all the repression and CIA-trained torture of dissenting voices involved. The history of the region, the nation and the time are an extremely critical part of the game, but more so are the people of Iran, both those guilty (to many) of instilling yet another oppressive government, and those innocent of anything beyond wanting happiness and a better life for their families. People just like those all over the world.

One of those innocent characters in 1979 Revolution: Black Friday is a young, male photojournalist named Reza Shirazi, who finds himself caught between his Shah-supporting family and his Ayatollah-supporting friends as he attempts to record the street revolt for posterity. And that’s basically the beginning of the game: Reza in a prison cell being tortured by an historical figure for information and connections, as the game proceeds in flashback form.

Much of 1979 Revolution: Black Friday is caught up in the minutia of the actual proceedings. The events, the people, the places are all (apparently) real, based on personal accounts and news reporting. The story may occasionally seem to bog down in the detailed use of Reza’s camera to record shots matching actual photos of the time, but goes far toward setting a precise, real mood for the player. Each photo taken presents the option to learn the reality behind that person or event, but may be (?) easily avoided on any subsequent playthroughs. When this game is presented as being “based on choices”, it’s an understatement, since choices have repercussions from small to large, and can come fast and furious. Outside the story itself are 39 Steam achievements based on those choices, included many multi-stage achievements. All indications based on the large number of choices are that this game warrants multiple playthroughs.

I was an young adult preparing to graduate college at the time of the 1979 Revolution, and I have distinct memories of the kidnapping and release of the American embassy hostages, as well as the resulting Iran-Contra scandal. Few things have shaken faith in government as universally in my lifetime as knowing that a soon-to-be president traded weapons for trusting American lives (as if baseball cards) with the nation considered by many to be our worst enemy (at that time calling us the great satan".) reviewText:
I got this game because it seemed like a grittier, more realistic take on a Telltale-like adventure game. It's certainly more realistic, but that's simply because of the subject matter: it's historical, not using some comic book or sci-fi movie as its foundation. Indeed, the setting and the events of the time are the most interesting parts of the game. Sadly, that's not enough to make a game good.

Just like an indie movie, the pacing struggles throughout. By far the best moments are when it picks up and you finally feel a sense of urgency. Unfortunately the same can not be said for a sense of agency. I got the impression that my choices would have very little effect on anything, and sure enough, they didn't.

The story focuses on a few different characters, but the length is so short and we know so little about them that it's hard to care aabout what happens. The culture and circumstances are also far enough away that they're difficult to relate to. And again, not having a lot of time to adjust makes it hard to immerse oneself in the world.

Every character felt like they were preaching about something - some viewpoint or moral or position. This added to a lack of emotion makes it a bit hard to stay invested and interested, as it sounds like you're just being lectured to for most of the game.

There are some neat collectibles; the photo mechanic to acquire them was fun and added to making the environments seem real. But the quick time events were annoying and not particularly well-exected. Some only flashed on the screen for a second or were hard to read while others used obscure icons with no text or explanation. Lastly, some of the collectibles were mutually exclusive with each other (for no good reason I could find) which meant having to restart a chapter to acquire them all. This was particularly frustrating because you can't skip dialogue or cutscenes and there's no sprint. In a word: slow.

The icing on the cake is an atrocious cliffhanger ending. Nothing is resolved, despite this supposedly being a full, standalone game.

This is a story worth telling, but a game might not have been the best medium for it. If you're heavily interested in the place and time then I'd probably still recommend it, but for everyone else I'd wait for an indie movie version. With a different ending it'd be worth the ticket price.

TL;DR: I recommend this game for fans of TellTale/Life is Strange or those interested in learning about history.

I picked up this game after reading about it on RPS and being a fan of TellTale Games and Life is Strange, as well as enjoying 'The Cat and the Coup', a short game about the overthrow of the democratically elected Iranian Prime Minister Mossadegh in 1953. I also like games where you learn things - I always faithfully read the historical notes in Assassin's Creed games and am pleased to see that this game crams in around 100 historical notes.

The game places you as Reza, a young photographer who becomes caught up with revolutionaries during the 1979 Iranian revolution. Similar to a TellTale game, you choose dialogue options based on a time limit and perform key-presses and QTEs for a couple of action sequences. The game also has a photography mechanic, linking the pictures you take to real photos from the time. There are 19 'chapters', which are better called 'scenes' due to their length.

The story is short, but gripping. It throws you straight into a situation and story you know nothing about (unless you're familiar with the 1979 revolution in Iran). This has its pros and cons. It means that you begin by making decisions without really knowing Reza, or why he might want to choose certain options. As you go on, you learn more about the political situation and Reza's life. Rather than creating a character from scratch, you often find things out in later chapters that make you wonder whether you made the right decision. This along with its length and the chance of finding all the historical notes certainly gives it more replay value than a TellTale adventure. However, it may have been nice to learn a bit more about Reza and Iran before being thrown into the story. The historical notes add depth to an otherwise limite story - there simply isn't enough time to build up a strong emotional connection to the characters. I'd say that the story is less character driven than politically driven. You find out more about the revolution, the factions and Iranian culture/history during the game and this informs your choices more than the relationships of the characters.

The game recommends headphones - I used them, but they aren't necessary. The audio is fantastic and helps put you right in the setting. Voice acting is also of a top, profesional standard and occasionally blends farsi phrases into the speech, so keep subtitles on because these are fully English.

However, the gameplay left some things to be desired. The time to choose dialogue option is too short. It makes conversations more realistically paced, but barely gives you the chance to read all the options before you choose. I also experienced some major, frequent framerate drops, and I'm running on a mid-to-high range gaming laptop.

Overall, I'd say this was a very good attempt at making a game that tells the sort of story rarely touched upon in video gaming. Games are often afraid to deal maturely with politics, either having an indistinguishable red/blue faction or a clearly evil enemy organisation. Real world politics is even less commonly used in games. 1979 Revolution deals with this well, teaching us that there is not necessarily a right or wrong side. Instead, politics is messy with many different groups pursuing goals for many different reasons. It has its flaws, so I wouldn't recommend it to everyone, but fans of adventure games or those interested in story-led games should definitely check it out; it's the same price as a movie ticket and the same length for a single playthrough.

reviewText:
With Never Alone and a few others, it's pretty cool to have videogames about different cultures and histories that you don't ever get in this medium. In this case it's Iran around the time of the Islamic Revolution when anti-establishment sentiment was soaring against the Shah totalitarian regime. It's fascinating to learn about that through the game while having a cohesive and compelling story so it doesn't feel like just a narrated walk through a museum exhibit. All the historical and cultural tidbits you learn and uncover makes for an enlightening experience like the political climate of the time such as about SAVAT or the Mujahideen, Iran's version of backgammon, the food, and why there was such an anti-American fervour.

The game plays like a historical Telltale game where you have player control and moral decisions to make but it's not quite an adventure game and more a cinematic experience. It's well-written drama with moving music and great voice acting. There are large crowd setpieces which are quite impressive for how much detail is packed in for a crowdfunded game (that missed its initial Kickstarter goal of $395K). There are sometimes QTEs which just reminded me of Indigo Prophecy and they can be silly but the most effective one is when you're moving between a hail of bullets and can die pretty easily, so patience and attention to audio cues is key. There's a framed narrative so you're reminiscing about this time of the 1979 Revolution while being interrogated and tortured. You play as Reza, who's a photographer struggling to remain neutral as it becomes increasingly harder to do at the cusp of a revolution. You've been away from the country so it's also a homecoming story. All the photograph taking reminded me of Beyond Good And Evil, so that was great. Often when you take a photo, you can read more info about the real event which reminded me of Never Alone's tapes.

There's a cast of characters that are all interesting (especially Bibi the woman leader of the protests, Babak the close friend, Ali the hothead, and Hossein your brother who's Shah security). Moral decisions relating to them can be trying with your own politics like whether violence such as throwing rocks during a protest is justifiable under such oppression. There's a particular one in the last quarter of the game that will feel like you're given nothing to make such a potentially devastating accusation or who to save which plays into the endings. There are 19 chapters, some of them can zip by in a few minutes while the ones where you're controlling Reza and navigating environments while interacting with hotspots can be longer, so overall it's a 2 hour experience. The story is eventful enough that it doesn't feel short but despite both endings, the abrupt ending(s) is a major cliffhanger. Abrupt not in an artistic sense where there's meaning to it but just as if there will be a continuation to do with other characters.

Despite the intense drama around the revolution, it was the smaller specific moments that stuck with me more. At one point that's not related to the plot, you can decide to pray or not. I've never seen muslim prayer in a videogame ever and have to say it was very faithful with even a step-by-step photo guide. From that prayer, you get a line of dialogue about Prophet Muhammad PBUH that can be used later on. My favourite sequence was spending time in your home with your family, viewing live-action photos, arguing with family members about this political situation, rummaging through items, and coming across this giant stack of home video tapes. The photos and home videos are all live-action which made me wonder if this was autobiographical in a way, and that kind of intimacy was exciting. I wanted to spend more time with these characters and this world, which is why I felt unsatisfied with the ending as I just wanted more. That is probably a good thing.

One of the most importatnt games I've ever played!

I saw say this game about a few weeks ago on IGN and was very intrigued. Here in the US, we don’t get much of anything about Iran, or the middle east for that matter, that isn’t Isis, “Bad” nuclear deal related, or how “PC” we have to be towards everyone. But we don’t ever really get a glimpse of what it might actually just to be a real human being in these places. 1979 Revolution: Black Friday does this.

So I’ll break down this review in different segments.

Visual: 1979 Revolution: Black Friday has a graphic novel style feel to it. Made with the Unity engine, which is a very accessible development tool for indie gaming. While not the most visually stunning game ever created, the game's distinct art style is very nice to look at. Plus the concept art is incredible. The environments look great, with great lighting especially in the interrogation scenes. The main characters look great. On a downside, some of the background character models are not quite up to par with the main characters, but it’s not a turnoff. Overall, I would say the visuals look great and work for the style of the game.

Audio: The voice acting in the game, are as good as any AAA title. With an extremely talented cast of Iranian actors the really bring it on the performance front. Navid Negahban (from Showtime's Homeland) in particular steals the show in the scenes that he is in. All the sounds from the environments are great as well, and really bring you to Tehran.

Gameplay: Very much Telltale-esk, the mix of choices, QTE, and Photography, Exploration all blend well together. The strength coming from having the real life pictures next to the one’s you took. I found myself meticulously trying to recreate all the photographs to the originals. Photos also provide a means to learn about the actual events, culture, and  people that influenced the Revolution. By the way, there is a tremendous amount of content in this game in regards to learning about the revolution, history, and culture of Iran. This is where the games stands apart from pretty much anything.

Story: It took me almost 4 hours to get through the entire game. I definitely took my time and tried to get every picture, and exploration point. I felt that the impact of my decisions also weighed heavily in big and small ways. For example when I picked the mole, to see the picture of the person I picked dead in a hole in the next interrogation scene really had an effect on me.

Amidst this crazy political season in the US, and all the events happening worldwide It’s incredibly refreshing to get a game that is as relevant in today's world as this one. Whether you're a democrat or republican, a communist or nationalist, this game presents the importance of everyday people taking a stand for what they believe in, and what happens with the consequences of those decisions.

reviewText:
If you've seen the 2012 movie Argo, you're probably somewhat familiar with the Iranian Revolution. But Argo only really touches on, one piece of the timeline of the revolution; the Iranian hostage crisis and the six Americans that escaped out of Iran. Black Friday seeks to tell the whole story of the Revolution, as a point-and-click adventure game.

You play as Reza Shirazi, a journalist, photographing the events of his home city, in Tehran, Iran. But there are multiple people in his life calling for him to join their side. Babak, his cousin, is involved with the protests of the revolution, but only wants to get their message across through nonviolence. Ali, his other cousin, is much more heavily involved with the revolution, and is willing to do anything to help the revolution, even if it means resorting to violence. While Reza's brother Hossein is a member of the SAVAK, Iran's police force, and persuades Reza to avoid going to the protests, out of fear that it will get their family in trouble. It's up to Reza to make a choice to merely take the role of a photographer, or revolutionary.

The gameplay should feel familiar to anyone who've played any Telltale's recent games, as it's clearly taking influence from their style. Can move around freely, in the parts of the game that aren't interactive cutscenes, and have a cursor you can use to examine anything in the environment. Many times you will be given up to four dialogue options at the bottom of the screen, which can affect how the game progresses. One gameplay mechanic that isn't taken from Telltale is the ability to take photos. As I said, you play as a photographer, and will be prompted to take photos of important events related to the Revolution. When in photo-mode you will see the photo-op as if looking through a camera, and must time the shot right in order to get a clear picture. Many of the pictures you take are inspired by real-life historical photographs, and the game will show you a comparisson page between the photo you took, and the real photo, along with historical facts relating to the photos.

This is actually a concept I'd wanted to see done in a game at some point. I love the idea of being a photographer, documenting history, and sometimes having to make a choice of exposing a moment of injustice, or intervening and stopping the injustice yourself.

The game does a good job at depicting the state of Iran in 1978-1980. You can feel the frustration and outrage the people of Iran feel. Everyone's attire looks appropriate for the period, and you get to see a lot of Iranian culture. It never ceases to give you interesting, and at times intense photo opportunities. Including one where you have to make a choice of whether to capture a photo of a policeman beating a protester, or running in and stopping the brutality.

The game also did a good job in humanizing the characters, even the ones that you might not like. For example, they make Hossein a very understandable character. He might be hard on Reza and angry at the revolution, but the game depicts him more as a man trying to continue to support his family and not lose his job, than just some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who abuses his power.

Also, like the game Never Alone, this is an excellent educational game. It clearly did its research on the historical events it presents to the player. I could ligitimately see this game being recommeneded to students by history professors in the future.

One complaint I do have is that this was a lot shorter than I'd thought it would be. I managed to complete it in about 90 minutes. And the game ends on a big cliff-hanger, which makes me hope that there's going to be more, like with Telltale's games. But as of writing this I haven't heard when or if any more episodes will be released, so I'm cautiously optimistic. I really hope we'll hear more about future episodes, as this game has me hooked.

If you're a fan of Telltale's games or you're a history junkie I would definitely recommened this game. The only thing I might advise is wait and see if a second episode will be released if you want a more longer experience.

reviewText:
iNK Stories and N-Fusion Interactive have taken the Telltale Games formula and applied it to a series of events that redefined a nation: the 1979 Iranian Revolution.  It combines dialogue choices, quick-time events, and a codex akin to historical footnotes for a narrative loosely guided by three young men. Reza Shirazi, the player’s character, is a photographer documenting the revolution at the behest of his childhood friend, Babak.  Players are quickly given the opportunity to take on a more insurrectionist role, and are encouraged by another character, Ali, to set aside the camera for a rock to throw at the police.

This choice, the balance between non-violent protest and full blown uprising, lies at the core of 1979 The Revolution in a way I’m still struggling with.  Is a peaceful option relevant if it won’t survive?  Is a violent movement better than the alternative? If you sacrifice your ideals to succeed, have you really succeeded?  I don’t know- and The Revolution won’t tell me.  Instead, it only makes you consider the struggle of people who have made that choice, are making that choice, and will make that choice in the future.  In forcing me to think heavily on this and in telling the story of Ali, Babak, and Reza, 1979 The Revolution: Black Friday succeeded.  Its failings lie in the most interactive trappings- it’s most game-like elements.

First and foremost- for a game that has you progressing down decision trees constantly and includes a Telltale-esque “Babak will remember that,” your selections don’t seem to have much of a meaningful impact outside of the immediate scene.  This may in fact be a good thing, as the tone of your answers can vary wildly from what you had imagined;  iNK Stories would have benefitted from something akin to Mass Effect’s Paragon/Renegade delineation.  In that same vein, silence is not always an option, instead, if a timer runs out Reza will reply with a pre-determined line which sometimes felt contrary to how he had behaved based on previous choices.  Finally, several of the quick-time events and interactions felt tacked on and broke up my interest in the story. Speaking as someone who doesn’t play many of them, I think The Revolution 1979 may have been better served as a visual novel, offering players a more focused narrative and dropping many of the interactive sections.

These issues are not the reason I will not be playing through the game for a second or third time.  I’m not interested in redoing my choices and seeing the alternatives because I am content with the story iNK Stories and N-Fusion led me through.  It wasn’t happy, and I think it could have been improved upon, but from an early confrontation with Ali, to a discussion of faith and power with other revolutionaries, and to a quiet moment of reassurance from Reza’s father, the story that was told is mine. I won’t play through the game again, but that doesn’t mean it’s done with me.  Despite its technical stumbles, 1979 The Revolution: Black Friday serves as a lens to not only learn about one of the defining moments of the last century, but to also consider the question, “What are my ideals worth?”  It’s a question I am going to spend a long time thinking about.

In modern days you will hear Iranian people comparing pre 1979 when people look normal (by western standards) and free because of their ability to express art, music, voting, media and clothing. Past 1979 is when this Muslim dictator began to enforce Sharia law and made women veil up, they were refused to vote, voting was totally rigged, music and art were suppressed, people’s liberties were crushed and the police was used as a form of gang to squash any opposition views by kidnapping them and killing them. reviewText:
If you like Telltale games with historical settings and great story telling, this game is for you.

However...

I have to warn you this. If you're expecting Telltale quality, you're dead wrong.

The story is great. I'm doing the second round of playing with different choices right now, so I cannot guarantee if there are multiple endings yet, but the game makes me feel like a lunatic when I go off the rails when I choose something the developer doesn't seem to like.

Say the first playthrough I'd go for a reasonably peaceful choice, but I'm going for all out violent options the second time around. What ended up happening is that I'd get ridiculous lines of dialogue the characters would say. It seems that the character the player plays (Reza) can be a reasonable guy a second, then a maniac another. It just seems forced into the game that once I make a violent option, I'm pretty much crapped out of the game atmosphere. However, it doesn't seem to change anything. The story still goes on.

So let me put down the pros & cons...

Pros:
- Great visuals (I'd rate this game a bit better than Telltale's game visual quality)
- Great story
- Emotional choices

Cons:
- Biased story (I know there's more to the actual story than what the game presents)
- Meaningless ending (Once it ends, I couldn't help but say, That's it?")
- Short game (~2 hours)

Good bang for the buck. I recommend the game

It's been a while since I played any game about Iranian history (which was The Cat and The Coup) and this game managed to revive my interest in its history again. 1979 Revolution: Black Friday is a really nice game to give an insight for players, whether they are Iranian or not, about the factors that led to 'Black Friday' and eventually the Revolution itself. But enough about that. Let's just see the pros and cons of this game, eh?

PROS
Great storytelling with the characters and their perspectives
Very informative about the game's historical setting (esp. the historical notes and pictures)
Graphics are pretty nice (not the best, but more than enough for this game)
Soundtrack and voice acting are also great.
'Twists' (?) in the story on some chapters that really makes you think twice about your choices
CONS
A very short game (2 hours to finish in a playthrough)
Abrupt ending (cliffhanger or some sorts?)
As some Steam reviewers have pointed out, some of the chapters are really short
Found a few bugs while walking about the game locations (not that annoying if you just waltz through the story)
Again as some folks have said, not a lot of replay value (the endings aren't really that different)
TL;DR Really enjoyed the game and its historical setting, but it's a bit short and the endings are really abrupt.

I really, REALLY hoped that the developers will make a sequel or more episodes from this game in the near future (I saw some articles that said they will do that, but CMIIW) because I genuinely can't wait to continue Reza's story during the Revolution again. It's not precisely a game that will make you play it multiple times, but if you're looking for a game that can explain the events leading to the Revolution in a fun and informative way without opening an extremely thick book, then this is the one for you.

reviewText: 1979 Revolution is harrowing, but very good. When i first saw it appear on Greenlight i voted it up immediately - Telltale-style interactive movies are not normally my cup of tea, but the idea of a game placing you as a photojournalist into a significant moment in history is genius. It does not disappoint. You don't even play anyone of consequence - you're just a kid with a camera - but that means you are really playing everyone of consequence. Walking amongst the youth, the radicals, the oppressed, the protestors... It's a unique opportunity to be able to document everyday people's lives, their struggle in a complicated time.\n\nThe sound design is exceptional, and the acting is perfect - it really feels like you are being caught up in a movement you can't control, something bigger than you - something exciting, frightening, confusing. My main complaint is that the camera is clumsy and keeps you trapped in small, barely-interactive areas, but that's fairly standard for this genre. This ain't no Life is Strange. But the setting is extremely refreshing - historical settings outside of the West are rare in gaming, and this is a particularly interesting one. The story builds well, the atmosphere is electric, and i had to blink away a few tears at the end. Excellent.

reviewText:
It's pretty dang short and it has a whole ton of unresolved plot threads. I'd like to see where they go, but we'll have to see if a sequel is made.

Since the game shows a point of view so often not seen in the West, I feel like it's definitely a good idea to try it for its pretty low price point.

Here is why you should get this game:

1. This is the only game I know of about this period of time that doesn't have a political agenda aside from telling this story from a layman's perspective. Reza starts as a sort of outsider having traveled abroad recently, so through his understanding we are able to see how the revolution looked to an everyman (at least in the first flashback sequence).

2. I like how all the pictures taken by the player throughout the game to progress the story are then linked up to the real life pictures that they're based on. It'd be nice if the focus didn't swing wildly back and forth, though.

3. In the scenes where the player is asked to explore the area there is a LOT of detail. I think my favorite scene in the game was going through Reza's house reading all of his parents' letters and watching their films.

4. The price point is a pretty fair one especially when it's on sale like it is now.

5. It lifts pretty heavily from the Telltale style of gameplay (QTE's, exploration sections, timed choices) so if you enjoy that style of storytelling this one fits the bill.

My major hang ups are:

1. The game assumes we know too much. It starts towards the end of things with Reza already a revolutionary working against the Islamic Republic government but his motivations for doing so and his disagreements with the new regime aren't explicitly laid out. All we know is that he doesn't like it.

2. The game leaves a lot of threads just hanging open. One of the major figures in the revolution the player joins seems to want a free Iran, free from the Soviets
hoursPlayed:
but what exactly that would look like is never really made clear. In addition none of the different parties involved in the revolution have their motivations made clear. The clerics want a cleric backed Iran, the Communists want a Marxist republic, the Mujahadeen want something unclear, but nobody says exactly what their version of Iran would be like. At one point the player has an opportunity to meet all these characters to try and understand them but it seems like it's mostly small talk. Then you never see any of them ever again.

3. The game gives you a bad choice. This is a bit of a spoiler, but the framed narrative for this game is Reza (the player character) is being interrogated by a member of the new government. During this interrogation, a family member joins in for leverage against Reza. Then later on the game gives you a Telltale style save this person or the other in a limited time" decision for that family member and another one. If you are paying attention you already know that one family member survives this (because he's with you during interrogation) so why on earth would you save him? He makes it!

reviewText: This is an important step in the history of gaming. A genuine (and successful) attempt to combine history and phillosophy with gaming in an engaging manner that functions both as a traditional game and an educational experience. It really brings the experience of the Iranian revolution to life, asking the player challenging questions and making them feel they're part of a real time of change and wonder which ideas they find most compelling. It elicits empathy for Iranian people and reminds us there was a time before the strict Islamic country it is now. That's important given the reputation Iranian people and the country has now.\n\nThe quicktime sections function well enough but not quite up to the standard of the likes of Telltale. The main problem for me is that the reading material and educational elements weren't quite as well integrated as one might hope. Certain sections were heavy on the additional optional reading material. I purchased this game after hearing an interview with the lead developer of iNK. I really, really wanted to like this game, but I just couldn't. I am giving it a reccomendation, only because I think the developer deserves it for putting so much of himself into this project. However:

As games go, it's not a very good one. Thre player is tasked with QUICKLY deciding lines of dialouge, most of the time having little context; little clue to what any of the choices even mean. The player is just expected to....pick one, just for the sake of picking one. Also, the game is more like a movie; one which plays out in front of you, and during which you can occationally either pass a QTE, or die.

As story telling goes, it's not very good either. There are two sides to every revolution, and this game CLEARLY tells only one. I would like to have learned about the Iranian revolution from both sides. In this case however, one side is sadistic and evil, and the other side is benevolant. That's rarely how revolutions go, and I've not doubt that this one didnt go this way either.
